2 October, 1911.

Imperial Medical College,

My dear Kwan:

ist audit sind ob od eonsdo s

od brotxe Your good letter has just been received, and it was a pleasure to

hear from you, even though the news which you send me is disappointing to 
us. We shall certainly miss you here in Andoher, and shall regret that you 
are no longer a member of the school. At the same time I have been somewhat 
prepared for this decision, for it hardly seemed to me likely that your father

would ask you to return to China if he expected to send you back again so soon

Anyway we shall always be glad to know that you are an Andover man in spirit, 
and I am confident that your interest in the old school will not die out as 
the years go by. I hope it may even increase. You have left many and warm 
friends behind you here, and among those I am glad to count myself one. As I 
told you when you left, I shall always deen it a privilege and real pleasure

to learn of your doings, and I shall expect to hear great things of you in the

days to come. You were certainly good to keep me so well posted in regard to

your travels by sending me cards from time to time, I was delighted to re -
ceive them all, but knew it was useless to reply, as you were constantly in

motion.

The year opens up for us here with a full school and prospects

of the usual enthusiasm and hard work. The swimming pool is nearly finished, 
and the new dormitorios are very popular with the boys. Lee and Lun Cho Sun 
spent the sumner at my brother's camp at Connecticut Lake, and I saw a good

metadata.name: Phillips Academy
metadata.abstract: Letter expressing regret that Sung Sing left Andover. Stearns states that he was prepared for this decision when Sung Sing's father called his son back to China. Stearns considers Sung Sing an Andover man in spirit and knows that he has many friends. Stearns is appreciative of Sung Sing's letters and will continue to be interested in hearing from him. He closes with comments about new dormitories and other projects; he notes that Lee and Lun Cho Sun spent the summer at Stearns' brothers camp and that Tommie Lee was also at the Lake and a fine man in the woods. A final bill will be sent soon.
metadata.collection: Head of School (Stearns) correspondence with Chinese alumni
